title-group.article-title: An Evidence-Based Review of the Current Treatment of Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

article-meta.aff: 1Saint Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston, NJ, USA
2Saint George’s University School of Medicine, Grenada, West Indies
3University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, Newark, NJ, USA

author-notes.corresp: Ronald S. Chamberlain, Department of Surgery, Saint Barnabas Medical Center, 94 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ 07039, USA Email: RChamberlain@barnabashealth.org

abstract.p: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is a rare but severe condition affecting 1 in 2000 to 3000 newborns with a survival rate of 67%. Although regular antenatal screening allows prenatal diagnosis in many cases, traditionally treatment has been based on postnatal surgical repair. Recent literature has pointed out the survival benefits of initial stabilization and the use of gentle ventilation strategies prior to definitive treatment, shifting the trend from immediate to delayed surgical repair. Advances in fetal intervention have allowed the introduction of fetal endoscopic tracheal occlusion as a method to hasten lung development before birth in order to minimize postnatal morbidity. Despite appropriate treatment, the long-term outcomes of these patients are plagued with numerous complications, associated with the primary pathology and also aggressive therapeutic measures. International centers of excellence have recently come together in an effort to standardize the care of such patients in hopes of maximizing their outcomes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a rare but severe condition affecting 1 in 2000 to 3000 newborns with a survival rate of 67%.1,2 Three different types of CDH have been described, which include a posterolateral Bochdalek-type (approximately 70%; Figure 1A), an anterior Morgagni-type (approximately 27%; Figure 1B), and a central septum transversum-type (approximately 2% to 3%). CDH defects can range from small subcentimeter defects to complete diaphragmatic agenesis. Bochdalek hernias, the most common variant, occur most often on the left side (85%), but can involve the right side (13%) or be bilateral defects (2%).3-6 The most common herniating organs are the small or large bowel (>88%), spleen (81%), and stomach (59%).7,8 A hernia sac is rarely present, and it can be difficult to distinguish true CDH from abnormal thinning of the diaphragm.7 Treatment of CDH is usually not difficult, as they can be repaired with either primary or patch closure; however, the clinical course of affected newborns is defined by the extent of respiratory failure at birth resulting from pulmonary hypoplasia, reduced airway branching, and decreased surfactant.9 Extensive muscularization of the pulmonary vessels may also occur resulting in primary pulmonary hypertension.10

caption.p: Types of diaphragmatic defects: (A) Bochdalek hernia and (B) Morgagni hernia

sec.p: Modern neonatal intensive care unit protocols have improved survival and reduced mortality to less than 10% to 20%,11 but this has come at the price of increased therapy-related complications such as bronchopulmonary dysplasia. This article aims to provide a comprehensive review of the embryological origins and pathogenesis of CDH as well as an evidence-based review of its current management and outcomes.

sec.title: Normal Development
sec.p: The normal diaphragm begins developing at approximately 4 weeks of gestation, originating from several distinct structures, which eventually fuse to form a solitary membrane dividing the thoracic cavity from the abdominal cavity.12 The anterior central tendon arises from the ventral body wall as the septum transversum while the pleuroperitoneal membrane arises from the posterolateral body wall and ultimately fuses with the esophageal mesentery to close off the pleuroperitoneal canals (Figure 2). The right side closes before the left side, possibly as a result of a more consistent surface provided by the right lobe of the liver.13 Myoblasts and phrenic axons subsequently migrate into this primordial structure to form the mature diaphragm.14

caption.p: Fetal development of the diaphragm: (A) Fusion of pleuroperitoneal membrane and septum transversum, (B) embryological origin of different parts of the diaphragm, (C) central tendon obliterating pleuroperitoneal canal, and (D) fully developed diaphragm

sec.title: Abnormal Development
sec.p: The precise embryologic origins of CDH remain controversial, although a number of animal models have been developed that have allowed hypothesis generation as to its origin. Historically, CDH were felt to result from a nonfusion of different parts of the diaphragm. This failed fusion permitted abdominal contents to herniate into the thorax as they reentered the abdomen from the embryonic coelom, thus leading to compression and dysgenesis of the lungs.15

A second hypothesis for CDH origin has implicated abnormal lung development as instrumental to abnormal diaphragmatic development16; however, this has been discredited since transgenic mice with no lungs still demonstrate normal diaphragmatic development.17 More recently a proliferative abnormality of the pleuroperitoneal folds has been suggested in the development of CDH.14,18 The theory proposes that failure of the pleuroperitoneal fold to fuse with the posthepatic mesenchyme may lead to the CDH defect.16 This process is associated with the liver herniating during early embryogenesis in mice and may also have a part in pulmonary hypoplasia.19 Finally some authors have suggested a double-hit hypothesis, theorizing that pulmonary development may already be defective before the actual hernia develops because of a “second developmental error.”10,20,21

sec.title: Molecular Basis of Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia Development
sec.p: Research in animal models has identified a number of affected genes in the pathogenesis of CDH; however, to date no single genetic defect has been firmly established. The implicated genes include Wilm’s tumor 1 (Bochdalek type),22 Platelet-derived growth factor receptor-α (Bochdalek type),23 Sonic Hedgehog (shh) pathway (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia in CDH),24 Fog2 pathway (Morgagni type),25 and the axon guiding gene Slit3 (central tendon type).26 An involvement of the retinoid acid pathway, including the aforementioned Fog2 mutations, has been elucidated in rodent models.27,28 Several authors have suggested a similar association in humans since it has noted that newborns with CDH have lower plasma retinol and retinol binding protein compared to matched controls.29 More recently, the Mathew–Wood syndrome, which includes diaphragmatic and pulmonary defects, has been associated with mutations in STRA6 (a part of retinoic acid pathway).30

sec.title: Diagnosis of Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia
sec.p: In most developed countries, up to two thirds of CDH cases are diagnosed during routine antenatal ultrasonographic (US) testing in the second or third trimester.31 A prenatal diagnosis of CDH should prompt transfer of the mother and fetus to a tertiary care center specialized in CDH cases either antenatally or at delivery.

Although US forms the basis of diagnosing CDH, it can also be used to assess the extent of herniation and associated mediastinal shift. A herniated liver is harder to identify using US because of its comparable echogenecity to the fetal lung, but indirect localization may be possible using Doppler localization of associated vessels. Doppler US can also be used to assess blood flow to the ipsilateral lung, which closely parallels lung development.32 Response of the fetal pulmonary vasculature to hyperoxygenation (mother breathing in 60% oxygen) has been assessed by Doppler flow measurements as a promising indicator for postnatal pulmonary vascular response.33

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is rarely needed to definitively diagnose CDH when US is equivocal, but its proven value lies in its ability to provide detail of the herniated viscera, as well as allowing for precise measurements for prognostic calculation.34 Fetal MRI can have a unique benefit in the setting of maternal obesity, oligohydramnios, fetal pelvic position, or thoracic pathology that may prevent a favorable acoustic window on US. MRI can also assess fetal lung volumes, which 3-dimensional US may fail to elucidate.35 This measurement can be used as a marker for the severity of pulmonary hypoplasia, the potential need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) as well as for predicting other long-term outcomes.36

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia cases diagnosed prenatally represent a higher risk cohort than those diagnosed at birth, probably attributable to a larger defect, which can be more easily imaged. However, that said, prenatal diagnosis also allows preplanned intervention before and immediately after delivery, which has resulted in a decreased mortality rate compared with less severe cases diagnosed postnatally.37

When CDH is diagnosed prenatally, maximal effort should be made to identify the lung-to-head ratio (LHR), liver position, and any associated anomalies that may adversely affect prognosis. In these cases, imaging and genetic testing are used in concert to accurately characterize whether the fetus has any additional disability that may be present so an individualized management plan can be devised and expectant parents can be appropriately counseled prenatally.

sec.title: Prognostic Indicators
sec.p: Extensive research has been conducted into various factors that may serve as prognostic indicators for babies born with CDH. Fetal analysis of absolute and observed/expected LHR, liver position, left- or right-sided defects, and large defects are commonly used examples of antenatal indicators.38-40 Although LHR is the most commonly used prognostic indicator, its predictive value is debated, especially since the normal LHR varies as the fetus develops. For this reason observed/expected LHR is considered a more accurate measure of outcomes.41,42 Liver position has recently gained popularity as a reliable prognostic indicator, predicting poor outcomes in cases diagnosed with liver herniation.2,39

Postnatally, the need for patch repair as opposed to primary repair, the pressure of the pulmonary circulation, coexisting anomalies, especially severe cardiac anomalies, and the duration of ECMO have also been correlated with worse outcomes.2 Most of these factors are indirect indicators of defect size and hence severity of the primary disease.

sec.title: Management
sec.p: The main tenets of CDH surgery have always been to reduce the herniated viscera and repair the defect as soon after birth as possible. However, the past 2 decades have seen a clear change in the management of CDH, with the focus shifting toward initial stabilization and delayed surgery with the use of lung preservation ventilation.11,43,44

sec.title: Ventilation Strategies
sec.p: A change in ventilating management strategies has been one of the most significant improvements in CDH management. It is imperative that ventilation strategies be decided early on since intubation is recommended immediately after delivery,45 and this is made easier when CDH is anticipated by prenatal diagnosis. Survival rates in the vicinity of 80% have been reported with the use of “gentle” ventilation.46,47 In modern facilities, newborns with CDH are immediately intubated in the delivery room with the goal of achieving a preductal saturation of 80% to 95% and a postductal saturation greater than 70%.45 Recent advances in management have allowed some specialized centers to achieve survival rates in the range of 75% to 90%,44,45,48-51 which is far superior to those reported in population based studies.43,44,52 These management strategies include less aggressive ventilation seeking a low peak inspiratory pressures (less than 20-25 cm H2O), minimal positive end expiratory pressures (2-5 cm H2O), permissive hypercapnia, the incorporation of high-frequency oscillation ventilation to prevent severe hypercapnia, and more liberal use of ECMO.

sec.title: Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation
sec.p: Approximately one third of patients born with CDH cannot be stabilized with assisted ventilation alone and ECMO is needed during initial hospitalization.53 The CDH EURO Consortium consensus45 statement has clearly defined the criteria for when ECMO should be considered. These are

list-item.p: Inability to maintain preductal SaO2 >85% or postductal SaO2 >70%
Acidosis with pH < 7.15 despite optimal ventilation
Peak inspiratory pressure >28 cm H2O or mean airway pressure >17 cm H2O are needed to achieve SaO2 >85%
Systemic hypotension resistant to fluid or ionotropic resuscitation, leading to urine output <0.5 mL/kg/h for 12 to 24 hours
Oxygenation index (mean airway pressure × FiO2 × 100/PaO2) ≥40 consistently present

sec.p: It is important to note that despite standard indications for ECMO use, there has been no clear demonstration of a survival benefit from ECMO use.54,55 When ECMO is used for patient stabilization, many centers recommend surgery while on ECMO. This strategy allows lung expansion, ameliorates mediastinal shift and prevents any added surgical stress or sudden increase in intra-abdominal pressure due to replaced viscera.56,57 Dassinger et al56 reported an improved survival among infants undergoing CDH repair while on ECMO (71%), which they attributed to early intervention before bowel wall edema could develop. In contrast, however, the Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia Repair (CDHR) group reported a higher mortality rate for repairs done on ECMO (50%) as compared with those done after ECMO (17%).58 While ECMO has been shown to increase risk of bleeding during surgical repair, this risk can be ameliorated by lowering activated clotting time to 145 to 165 seconds, using transexamic acid or aminocaproic acid, maintaining platelet levels greater than 100 × 109/L for at least 24 hours postoperatively and using meticulous surgical technique.56,59

sec.title: Management of Pulmonary Hypertension
sec.p: The aim of treatment for pulmonary hypertension (PHTN) is to minimize pulmonary vascular pressures while avoiding systemic hypotension. By necessity this implies tolerating a small degree of right-to-left shunting. First-line therapy for persistent PHTN is inhaled nitric oxide (iNO), particularly when there is either an oxygenation index of 20 or higher and/or a preductal–postductal saturation difference of 10% or higher.45 Despite the lack of any proven survival benefit, iNO may be useful as a temporary bridge to improve the neonate’s condition long enough to allow transfer to a specialized center. If iNO does not improve PHTN, intravenous prostaglandin E1 or oral sildenafil (a phosphodiesterase inhibitor) may be used in case of suprasystemic pulmonary artery pressures and right-to-left shunting.45,60 The degree of PHTN and its response to these therapies can be assessed noninvasively by consecutive echocardiograms. Of note however, despite anecdotal reports of their usefulness in individual cases, no clear benefit has yet been shown in studies conducted to evaluate the efficacy of either iNO or phosphodiesterase inhibitors.61-63

sec.title: Surgical Management
sec.p: Modern surgical management of CDH has shifted from emergency surgery to semi-elective surgery after initial stabilization. The CDH EURO Consortium consensus45 has generated guidelines that help identify candidates stable enough for surgical repair. Surgical candidates are expected to fulfill the following criteria:

list-item.p: Mean arterial blood pressure is normal for gestational age,
Preductal saturation level is between 85% and 95% on FiO2 <50%,

sec.p: Both open and minimally invasive thoracic or abdominal approaches have been described and debate continues regarding the ideal technique. Laparotomy is used most commonly and has several well described advantages over thoracotomy, including easier reduction of intra-abdominal viscera, ability to mobilize the posterior rim of the diaphragm for closure, easier manipulation of the intestines in cases of rotational abnormalities, and avoidance of thoracotomy-associated musculoskeletal abnormalities.64 That said, laparotomy has been associated with an immediate deterioration in respiratory function despite long-term improvement.65 This deterioration is likely related to increased abdominal compartment pressure and a staged closure with prosthetic silo has been suggested by some to ameliorate this anticipated outcome.66,67

Minimally invasive surgical approaches offer the advantages of smaller incisions, decreased risk of incisional hernias, decreased chest deformity, reduced postoperative pain, and possibly better postoperative pulmonary compliance.68 Concerns related to this approach focus on the insufflation of CO2, which may be systemically absorbed in a neonate who already has respiratory compromise and which may potentially lead to worsening hypercapnia and acidosis.69,70

Minimally invasive CDH repairs were first attempted through a laparoscopic approach, but since then thoracoscopic approaches has been favored as they provide a better view of the defect, and greater working space after reduction of the herniated viscera. Selection criteria for those newborns who may be considered candidates for minimally invasive surgery remain in development. Factors which have shown promise as indicators of successful thoracoscopic surgery include the liver and stomach located in their normal anatomic position, absence of significant cardiac anomalies, absence of preoperative ECMO, peak inspiratory pressure ≤26 cm H2O, and no clinical evidence of PHTN.71,72 Notably, certain centers of excellence have successfully used thoracoscopic approaches even with the most challenging cases, including patients on ECMO, right-sided defects, or patch repair.73,74 Disadvantages of thoracoscopic approach include a higher recurrence rate, greater operative time and the inability to perform a prophylactic Nissen fundoplication for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in those at high risk.

Laparoscopic approach remains ideal for Morgagni type CDH since these defects are relatively small anterior defects that can be easily visualized laparoscopically and insufflation with CO2 may actually reduce the hernia.75 Thoracoscopic approaches are inadequate in visualizing these defects without mediastinal dissection. Open surgery though feasible, is usually avoided in favor of minimally invasive surgery since these patients are stable and relatively older.76

sec.title: Patch Repair
sec.p: Normal functioning of the diaphragm requires it to maintain its anatomical dome-shape when relaxed. To this end, CDH repairs need to ensure an appropriate amount of laxity, necessitating use of patches in larger defects. About half of all CDH patients require a patch.53 Certain factors can predict the need for patch repair preoperatively, including high PaCO2 levels (>34 mm Hg) and the need for ionotropes.77 Various synthetic (polytetrafuoroethylene) and bioprosthetic (porcine small intestine– or dermis-derived matrices) materials have been used in patch repairs.78 Synthetic patches have been associated with recurrence rates of up to 50%, which occur in a bimodal fashion as either early (2-7 months) or late (20-51 months).79,80 This recurrence rate can be lowered by utilizing reinforcing techniques such as constructing cone-shaped, double fixed patches,81 but nevertheless there is an inherent negative effect of patch repair on overall development, with the patch acting as a tethering point leading to musculoskeletal deformity.82

In an effort to avoid complications associated with synthetic patches, biological meshes such as Surgisis (porcine small intestine submucosal matrix) have been used and are associated with lower risk of infection and a decreased tethering effect as the patient grows. Despite these advantages however the risk of recurrence remains high even with a biologic mesh.83 Recent studies have suggested that Permacol (porcine dermal collagen matrix) may uniquely allow for a more pliable diaphragm and a reduced recurrence rate,80 but additional studies are needed to confirm this observation.

To avoid patch repair, various autologous muscle flaps have been used to bridge the CDH defect. The advantages of autologous vascularized flaps are obvious in that they can grow with the child.84 Phrenic nerve grafting may also aid the flap in developing some diaphragmatic function.85 Muscle grafts have been used successfully in patients on ECMO and dissection in the avascular planes between muscles has minimized the risk of bleeding.86

Regardless of the type of patch material used, CDH requiring patch repair are associated with worse outcomes, which likely reflects the severity of the CDH defect rather than inherent problems with patch repair.83

sec.title: Fetal Surgery
sec.p: Enhanced ability to make an antenatal diagnosis of CDH provides a window for possible antenatal interventions in hopes of improving outcomes in severe CDH cases. Various experimental surgical procedures have been performed in animal models but to date only a few have been performed in humans, the most promising being fetal endoscopic tracheal occlusion (FETO).87

Fetal endoscopic tracheal occlusion aims to accelerate lung growth by temporarily occluding the trachea with a balloon that is removed at 34 weeks of gestation. This technique has been shown to improve both LHR and pulmonary blood flow, both good prognostic indicators.88 However, whether FETO affects survival is still under considerable debate since the 2 largest FETO studies have shown contrasting results. Harrison et al89 failed to show a survival benefit in a randomized controlled trial comparing FETO with standard postnatal care (n = 24) while exposing the fetus to risks of intervention, as a result the study was terminated prematurely. In contrast, Jani et al90 showed a significant improvement in observed/expected LHR after FETO (n = 210), which they used to postulate a potential survival benefit.

sec.title: Standardized Protocols
sec.p: Numerous authors have documented improved survival in newborns with CDH following the implementation of standardized protocols at centers of excellence.37,91 Standardization beyond the institutional level is only possible with international collaboration, and at present these initiatives are being led by various groups, including the CDH study group and the CDH EURO Consortium.45

sec.title: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease
sec.p: A large percentage of CDH patients (20% to 81%) suffer from intractable GERD following surgical repair. These symptoms have been primarily attributed to either the diaphragmatic defect, associated abnormal anatomy of the esophagus, altered intra-abdominal/intrathoracic pressure dynamics, or direct tension on the esophageal sphincter following CDH repair.92,93 Severe GERD can markedly alter infant growth if left untreated, and although some children improve with conservative management, more than half require surgical management of their symptoms. The most important predictor of the need for surgery to manage GERD symptoms is the need for patch repair of the diaphragmatic defect, leading most pediatric surgeons to routinely perform a Nissen’s fundoplication when a patch is used to repair the CDH.94

sec.title: Pulmonary Abnormalities
sec.p: As many as 50% of CDH survivors will experience some form of chronic lung disease, including obstructive, restrictive, or mixed pulmonary function abnormalities. To some extent, nearly all infants have at least some degree of pulmonary hypoplasia, which tends to persist even after surgical repair, documented with V/Q scans.94,95 Patients treated with ECMO or requiring patch repair (an indicator of a larger defect) are at even greater risk of short- and long-term pulmonary morbidity. Fortunately for most children, chronic lung disease tends to improve as the child develops, and its prevalence decreases markedly after the first year of life.96

sec.title: Failure to Thrive
sec.p: Failure to thrive has been reported in as many as 30% of CDH survivors despite adequate caloric intake; however, growth tends to improve between age 6 months and 2 years with conservative management having similar outcomes to more aggressive therapies.94 The etiology for failure to thrive tends to be multifactorial, including but not limited to GERD. Other possible causes include chronic lung disease and oral aversion. Gastrostomy tube may be required to maintain appropriate growth in severely affected infants, more frequently in those who have been treated with conventional ventilation compared with lung protective ventilation.97

sec.title: Neurological Deficits
sec.p: Neurological sequelae are seen most commonly in CDH survivors who have been on ECMO. Sensorineural hearing loss is the most common sequela but typically improves as the child grows.94

sec.title: Skeletal Abnormalities
sec.p: The most common structural anomalies are chest asymmetry and pectus deformities followed by vertebral anomalies such as kyphosis and scoliosis. These deformities may originate from abnormal fetal development or postsurgical tethering.94

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is a rare congenital defect that continues to be associated with poor postnatal outcomes despite significant advances. A recent transition in ventilation strategies toward a lung protective approach has helped improve survival. Surgical correction of the defect remains the gold standard, and recent international collaborations have suggested delayed repair may be preferable till the newborn is stabilized. Fetal intervention for CDH and other congenital abnormalities is a rapidly developing field that may result in improved outcomes through the utilization of such techniques as FETO in the period between diagnosis and birth. A comprehensive understanding of the embryologic processes leading to the development of CDH is a sine qua non to deciding on the appropriate surgical repair.
